"Executive action" may also mean, generally, an action taken by the [[executive branch]] of a government without [[legislative]] approval; for example, an [[executive order]]}} '''Executive Action''' is a term used by the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] starting in the early 1950s to refer to [[assassination]] operations. These operations were often conducted by the CIA's [[Division D]], a subsection of the agency's Directorate of Operations. "Executive Action" operations conducted by the CIA ranged from an attempt to kill [[Fidel Castro]] using a cigar injected with [[Botulism]] toxin to an alleged plan to kill rebel leader [[Che Guevara]]. The [[Ford administration]] forbade assassination in 1976 with [[Executive Order 11905]]. A ''[[Washington Post]]'' article, c. 1989{{Verify source|date=January 2010}}, reported that a 'secret' ruling of the [[U.S. Department of State]]'s Office of Legal Advisor interpreted{{Verify source|date=January 2010}} Ford's Executive Order to ban only intentional killings of foreign leaders, thus clearing the way for 'accidental' killings of foreign leaders -- for example, during the confusion of a coup or invasion. As this ruling was one of at least four preceding the [[United States invasion of Panama|U.S. invasion of Panama]], some{{Who|date=January 2010}} saw the ruling as giving a green light for [[Manuel Noriega]] to be killed 'accidentally.' Noriega survived the invasion and surrendered to US forces. == See also == *[[Targeted killings]] *[[Disposition Matrix]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Executive Action}} [[Category:Central Intelligence Agency]] [[Category:Homicide]] [[Category:Central Intelligence Agency operations]] {{US-hist-stub}}
